You only need minutes to start a Windows Server and Linux Server and can completely control servers in the cloud and perform maintenance based on your business needs.

You only need minutes to start a Windows Server and Linux

  • Very large scale is going from one to thousands of virtual machine instances
  • Built-in virtual networks and load balancing
  • Achieve a consistent mixed environment with a local environment
  • Supports Linux, Windows Server, SQL Server, Oracle, IBM and SAP
  • Charging by the minute to economize costs

You can use Azure virtual machines to image a Windows Server, Linux, or third-party software to Azure. You can choose from a warehouse of images or use your own custom image.

Azure image warehouse provides the following versions of Windows Server: Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Server 2012 and Windows Server 2012 R2.

Azure image warehouse provides the following versions of SQL Server: all versions of SQL Server2014, SQL Server 2012, and SQL Server 2008 R2.

Warning:

Azure Virtual Machine Disk includes a temporary disk, D: disk (Windows) or /dev/sdb1 (Linux). They only provide temporary storage, so that there is the risk of lost data and data is not backed up. The common reason this situation occurs is when virtual machines migrate onto different mainframes. Causes of virtual machine migration include adjusting the size of a virtual machine, replacing a mainframe, or a hardware failure.

Using an image built by the SQL Server Team, you can effortlessly set up a SQL Server in a few minutes. You can use the free MSDN licensed virtual machine environment to focus on rapid development/testing. You can also use SQL Server AlwaysOn across multiple Azure regions to deploy complicated apps you have created.

When deploying a virtual machine into Azure, you pay by the minute for fast computer mode workloads, rapid development and testing environments, and frequent stop and start scenarios. It includes Windows, Linux, and SQL Server all charged by the minute. You even can automatically scale your entire platform based on planned or instance CPU use rates. Hybrid Connections

Using virtual networks, you can control and configure all aspects of your network, define a subnetwork, and preferred DNS IP. You can, through the Internet, use a secure path through a VPN into Azure to reach your virtual machine.

This service includes load balancing across instances and ease of configuration. You can set up Load Balancer and add secure ACL to control access. Moreover, you can define specific instrumentation to help you monitor running applications. All of this can be done through an easy-to-use portal.

Faster, bigger, and better D series virtual machines

You can now deploy an even bigger D series virtual machine to satisfy you load balancing requirements. This size of virtual machine runs faster and stronger and handles faster device speeds. Internal storage is greater and provides easier virtual machine extremely fast temporary storage based on a temporary disk supported by SSD storage. You have to try it out to see how fast it is! Experience it yourself today.

It uses Dv2 and DSv2 series virtual machine functionality

The Dv2 series virtual machine is an improvement over the D series virtual machine and provides an even stronger CPU. The Dv2 series is based on the newest generation 2.4 GHz Intel Xeon E5-2673 v3 (Haswell) processor and uses Intel Turbo Boost technology 2.0, which can exceed a speed of 3.2 GHz. The DSv2 is based on the Dv2 adding Azure Advanced Storage to provide high-performance permanent disk. Speaking of the need for an even faster CPU, better local disk performance, or higher enterprise-level storage apps, the DSv2, Dv2 and D series combined can provide even stronger functionality.

TextpageLeftNav.metaDescription: Azure Virtual Machines (Virtual Machines) can rapidly set up scalable Linux or Windows servers and allocate virtual machine resources locally or from the cloud. Built-in virtual networks and load balancing achieve a consistent hybrid environment with a local environment that supports Microsoft SQL Server and SharePoint Server. You can use Azure virtual machines to deploy Windows Server, Linux, or third party software images to Azure and choose from a warehouse of images or use your own.
